dashboard.label: NMON Performance Monitor
dashboard.description: NMON Performance Monitor for Unix and Linux Systems - Version 1.7.4

div.data-options: { "user_slides":"scc-takethetour-slides", "width":"60", "title":"Nmon Performance : Take the tour !", "close_btn_label":"Close", "no_more_label":"Do not show this again", "no_more_cookie_name":"scc_takethetour_v1.6.16", "hide_container":false, "show_credits":true }

ul.li:
WELCOME IN NMON PERFORMANCE FOR SPLUNK ENTERPRISE !
Glad to see you there ! Nmon Performance is the place for Unix & Linux system performance and monitoring for Splunk Enterprise.
Click on the next slide and start discovering the application!

EASY DEPLOYMENT FOR YOUR SERVERS:
A Technical Addon (TA-nmon) is provided in the resources directory of the Nmon Application core package, deploy this Technical Addon to your Unix or Linux servers, and that's it. The TA-nmon will automatically generate the nmon data, and your system data will automatically be available in Splunk.
The TA-nmon configuration can be easily managed with various options available and centralized:

ACCESSIBLE AND EFFICIENT MACHINE DATA:
The Nmon Performance application implements a native Splunk abstraction layer known as "eventtype", this provides an easy, customizable and structured access to every piece of data.
Home pages will provide rapid access to every piece of data:

INTEGRATED NAVIGATION:
Most of interface and dashboard implements the a main link to the "integrated navigation", in other word an integrated window that provides access to related raw data, metrics or interface.
Integrated navigation has been designed to provide a global scheme of navigation for better user experience:

NMON INVENTORY REPORTING:
The nmon raw data contains a large amount of various configuration items that are generated during the nmon binary processing steps, these items are known as the AAA and BBB data.
Splunk will automatically and efficiency extract main items of system information and configuration into the central nmon_inventory lookup table, which is also being exploited in the application context:

NMON SUMMARY LIGHT:
The NMON SUMMARY LIGHT interface is an advanced dashboard that has been designed to give an instant picture of the status of your system.
This interface provides a global view of the host configuration, and key system metrics utilization over time. Optionally, active buttons will activate advanced and details views of the performance metrics.

NMON WALL OF PERFORMANCE:
The Wall Of Performance is a real time and multi-server oriented view designed to provide a fast and quick overview monitoring of your system utilization.
Active buttons gives access to advanced metrics and views, and this dashboard can be easily cloned and exported anywhere in Splunk, to be customized with a list of servers to be monitored.

NMON ANALYSER:
The NMON ANALYSER interface will exploit every available metric to the host and operating system, it has been initially inspired by the well known Excel datasheet.
This interface provides an high and accurate level of information for system experts, and should be used for focussed time range for performance trouble shooting or analysis purposes.

NMON BASELINE:
The NMON BASELINE interface is an advanced analysis of system key metrics using massive historical data, once per week the baseline are calculated over past months of data and results are stored in mondoDB KVstores.
During the analysing operation, the interface will estimate upper, expected and lower baselines of the metric with a seasonal perspective (comparing time interval per day of the week), This can be even improved with business insights. (such as ignoring bank holidays, specific commercial periods...)

NMON PREDICTIVE:
The NMON PREDICTIVE interface implements the "predict" forecast command to generate data prediction using machine learning and Kalman filter.
The interface has been totally rewritten to be much more simple and efficient, in default configuration the interface will generate predictions for next 3 months using past 3 months of data.
Many options of the predict command can be easily changed within the interface to match your needs.

ACCESSIBLE DEDICATED INTERFACES FOR EACH METRIC:
Each main type of performance metric has a dedicated interface for focused analyses, simply organized and easily accessible.
These interfaces intends to provide easy access to data and servers, with simple and advanced functions such as time filtering and aggregation for complex and long term analysis:

HOWTO INTERFACES, MANAGE NMON DATA WITH THE SPLUNK LANGUAGE PROCESSING:
Various semi-interactive Howto interfaces will guide you to use the Splunk Language Processing and start easily exploiting the nmon data on your own.
Howto interfaces are implemented for main performance metrics and provide sample SPL searches for various type of operation such as table stats calculation, charting, alerting:

PIVOT DATA MODELS INTENSIVE IMPLEMENTATION:
For very high performance and efficient data manipulation, the Nmon Performance application intensively implements Pivot Data models.
Being used in many of available interfaces, each Pivot is easily accessible from the structured pivot app bar menu:

ALERTING & SAFE CENTER:
Various alerts are configured by default for main system metrics to provide an instant view of servers currently in high level of utilization.
The SAFE CENTER interface provides a summary and historical view of these alerts:

ADVANCED ANALYSIS & COMPARISON:
Various advanced analysis can be achieved through provided interfaces such as the comparison interface that allows comparing performance between specific time periods.
Charting accuracy is a master piece of the Nmon Performance application with the use of custom macros charting for best accuracy:

DATA DICTIONARY:
A data dictionnary dashboard exploits the data_dictionary lookup table containing a full description of almost every metrics, fields and associated formula used in the application.
This view implements search table forms and a dendogram form to visualize metrics hierarchy:

BULLET DASHBOARD & OTHERS:
Various dashboards are provided with the goal to manage main resources utilization metrics such as CPU and Memory in a global and aggregated perspective.
The new Bullet Dashboard is one example of these dashboards:

div.p:
The SUMMARY LIGHT interface is a single-server view that provides main system metrics information from one view, such as CPU utilization, memory and processes statistics.
This dashboard provides an easy and fast view of key system metrics of your server.

The WALL OF PERFORMANCE interface is a multi-server advanced view that proposes from a single page most system metrics activity in single forms visualizations.
Each metric can be activated to access within the same page time oriented advanced charts.
This dashboard can be easily cloned to customize the list of servers to be monitored, and will be usable anywhere in Splunk, in or out of the Nmon App.

p.b: Nmon Analyser interfaces provides full reporting of almost every monitor available within the application and for the operating system concerned.
p.i:
Nmon Analyser interfaces have been designed for focused time ranges, very large time ranges may require time to be fully processed.
For long time analysis, please consider using metric dedicated interfaces available from App home pages

div.p:
NMON BASELINE interfaces provides an advanced system key metrics reporting to help detecting derivation anomalies based on past data history analysed and stored in KV stores.
The baseline is evaluated over a large dataset of past resources usage and allows determining if the current utilization level represents a potential derivation or normal conditions of use.
With the capacity of charting in the future, you can follow within the day resources usage and easily estimate what is probably not a normal situation for your specific system usage.

h4.i: Data Categories: Explore All / Event Types: nmon:performance (Performance data), nmon:config (Configuration data), nmon:collect (Nmon raw data generation), nmon:processing (Nmon raw data processing) - About Nmon Performance Monitor

div.div:
The Nmon application implements eventtypes to provide an easy and structured access to every piece of data within the app.
On the top most level, the main eventtype provides access to all raw data:

On sub-levels, Top interest eventtypes will contain the performance metrics data (nmon:performance) and configuration data (nmon:config) The nmon:collect eventtype contains information about nmon processes generation that will collect the performance and configuration data on servers. The nmon:processing eventtype contains information about processing steps that converts the nmon data into usable data for Splunk.

In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:performance eventtype contains all the data related to performance metrics of your systems.
In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:config eventtype contains all the data related to the configuration of your systems.
These are the AAA and BBB* sections of nmon raw data, generated during the nmon binary startup.
The events are long multi-lines events stored per host, in default configuration these data will be extracted almost every 2 hours as the data will not change unless a new nmon process gets launched.

The nmon:config data is associated with the generation of the nmon_inventory lookup and the Nmon_Config data model.
The nmon_inventory lookup table is being generated by a scheduled report (which runs by default every hour) that extracts main configuration items (number of CPUs, volume of physical memory...) from the nmon:configuration data over the Nmon_Config data model.
Once the nmon_inventory data has been generated, it is ready to be used and explored within various interfaces.

The nmon:collect eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processes generation on your systems.
These are the ouput of the input script "nmon_helper.sh" thats gets automatically launched by Splunk when deploying the Nmon App.
By default, the nmon_helper.sh script gets started every minute, its main job is to verify the status of the current nmon process, and start a new one if conditions requires it.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

The nmon:processing eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processing steps that converts nmon data into usable data for Splunk.
These are the ouput of nmon2csv Python and Perl parsers provided within the App.
Every time an existing raw nmon file is updated, or a new one gets created, Splunk will call parsers scripts and generate appropriated data.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

single.option: DATE OF FIRST AND LAST PERF EVENT

search.ref: Hosts with data within last 7 days

drilldown.link: search?q=| pivot NMON_Config Nmon_Config dc(hostname) AS "dcount" SPLITROW _time AS _time PERIOD day SORT 0 _time ROWSUMMARY 0 COLSUMMARY 0 NUMCOLS 0 SHOWOTHER 1

search.ref: Number of Errors in Data Processing or Data Collect since last 24 Hours

drilldown.link: search?q=(eventtype=nmon:processing OR eventtype=nmon:collect error) OR (index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd ERROR ExecProcessor nmon) NOT ("There is no python in" OR "python: not found") earliest="-24h" latest="now"

h4.i: Enter Splunk Triggered Alerts for Nmon App - Enter Nmon SAFE CENTER dashboard

search.ref: SAFE CENTER - Number of active CPU alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active Real Memory alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active Virtual Memory alerts
SAFE CENTER - Number of active FS alerts

span.title:
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%)
• Represents the percentage of CPU system load for all available cores
• Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

a.span: ALL OS: Percentage of CPU Utilization

span.title:
CPU Utilization per logical core statistics in Percentage (%)
• Represents the percentage of CPU system load by logical core (lower level of CPU usage details)
• Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

a.span: ALL OS: Percentage of CPU Utilization per logical core

span.title:
IBM Power partitions statistics
• A Micro Power Partition (AIX or PowerLinux) returns various CPU utilization statistics in virtual CPUs units
• Additionnaly, the Partition is able to return statistics about the Pool that hosts the partition

a.span: AIX / PowerLinux: Virtual Partition and Pools CPU Utilization

div.p:
The LPAR monitor contains various CPU related metrics about Partitions and Pools utilization.
These metrics are available on AIX and PowerLinux partitions. (PowerLinux must run at least nmon 16e versions)
To be able to retrieve Pools related statistics, the partition must be authorized to do so in the HMC configuration for the Pseries.

span.title:
Virtual CPU Utilization of PSeries Pools (same as part of LPAR with some additional monitors)
• For IBM P5 generation and less, a Micro Partition that has App access will return the load of the PSeries
• For IBM P6 generation and more, a Micro Partition that has App access will return the load of it's Pool, and the load of the PSeries if it is part of the DefaultPool
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%) for Workload Manager

div.p:
Workload Manager statistics for AIX and Solaris contains various performance metrics about Workload classes.
Depending on the operating system, this monitor includes CPU, Memory, Block I/O statistics.

span.title:
Statistics of Main Processes System Resources Usage
• Get the CPU core utilization of main processes aggregated by Command invocations
• Others Statistics available: Real/Virtual memory usage, minor and major faults and more
• With UARG information, filter PIDs from Command to get accurate measures of complex processes

a.span: ALL OS: Main Processes System Resources Usage

div.p:
The TOP monitor provides essential resource usage statistics of processes, and has specific interfaces per operating system.
Depending on the operating system, this monitor may include on a per process level CPU usage, Physical and Vitual memory usage, number of threads, Major and Minor faults...

span.title:
Search for PIDs, Commands and Full Arguments of Processes
• With UARG, get detailed information about Commands registered: PID, Full arguments and more
• These information can also be very useful within TOP interfaces for accurate analysis

a.span: ALL OS: Search for PIDs, Commands and Arguments

p.b: The UARG monitor provides PID information with full commands arguments, and has specific interfaces per operating system.

span.title:
Various Kernel File statistics
• Read / Write System calls and other statistics

I/O Adapters Statistics
• Data Rate (Kbytes/sec) and Total I/O Operations (tps) per Adapter Interfaces

Fiber Chanel Interfaces Statistics
• Data Rate (Kbytes/sec) and Total I/O Operations (tps) per Fiber Channel Interfaces

Kernel Internal Statistics
• RunQueue, Swap-In, pswitch, syscall, fork, exec and more

Solaris Processes Activity Statistics
This interface will return the percentage of time processes have spent in, such as
• % of Time in User / System / mode, % of Time processing system traps
• % of Time waiting for CPU, and more

a.span: SOLARIS: Percentage of Time Processes have spent in

span.title:
Paging Statistics
• Pages In / Pages Out (pgsin / pgsout)
• Fs In / Fs Out (sum of pgin/pgsin and pgout/pgsout per interval)
• Scan Free Ratio (Pages scans by reclaims per interval)
And more

Various Virtual Memory statistics
• Pageins / Pageout
• Swapins / Swapout
• Minor and Major faults
And more

a.span: LINUX, SOLARIS: Kernel Virtual Memory Statistics

p.b: The VM monitor provides advanced virtual memory statistics for Linux and Solaris systems, and has specific interfaces per operating system.

span.title: Block I/O statistics in Percentage (%) for Workload Manager

Memory Allocation Statistics
• Analyse Memory allocation by main categories: FSCache, Process, System, Free
• Global Memory rate utilization

Real and Virtual Memory Statistics
• Memory Usage in Data Volume (MB) or Percentage
• Specific System Stats (for Linux: Buffers / Cached / Active / Inactive...)

a.span: ALL OS: Real and Virtual Memory Statistics

p.b: The MEM monitor provides various essential memory utilization statistics and has specific interfaces per operating system.

span.title:
Various Memory Statistics
• Cache Hit Ratio, System Buffer Accesses...

p.b: The MEMUSE monitor is dedicated to AIX and Solaris systems only, and it has specific interfaces per operating system.

span.title: Memory Utilization statistics in Percentage (%) for Workload Manager

div.p:
Workload Manager statistics for AIX and Solaris contains various performance metrics about Workload classes.
Depending on the operating system, this monitor includes CPU, Memory, Block I/O statistics.

span.title:
Transfer Statistics per Disk
• Average data size per block device transfer per disk (KBytes per transfer)

a.span: ALL OS: Average Data Transfer Size

span.title:
Percentage of Time Busy Disk
• Analyse the Percentage of Time a disk was busy

a.span: ALL OS: The Percentage of time a disk was Busy

span.title:
Disks Read and Write Data rate
• Analyse Disk Read and Write operation Data rate in Kbytes/sec

a.span: ALL OS: Disk Read/Write Data Rate

span.title:
Disks I/O per second
• Numbers of Input / Output operations per second (formerly IOPS) by disk

a.span: ALL OS: Disk I/O Operations per second (IOPS)

span.title:
Disks Read and Write I/O per second
• Read or Write Numbers of Input / Output operations per second (formerly IOPS) by disk

a.span: ALL OS: Disk Read/Write I/O per second (IOPS)

span.title:
(ms) Average service time by disk
• Same as 'sar -d.avserv'
• Same as 'iostat -xn.asvc_t'. For iostat, a disk is referred as a device'

(ms) Average wait time by disk
• Same as 'sar -d.avwait'
• Same as 'iostat -xn.wsvc_t'. For iostat, a disk is referred as a device'

File Systems Percentage Usage
• Percentage usage of different file systems available

a.span: ALL OS: File systems Percentage Usage

span.title:
File Systems Inode Percentage Usage
• Percentage Inode usage of different file systems available

a.span: AIX: File systems Inode Percentage Usage

span.title:
Network Traffic per interface
• Analyse Traffic Data per interface in Kbps / Mbps / Gbps and per host

a.span: ALL OS: Traffic Data Rate per Interface

span.title:
Network Packets per interface
• Analyse the Number of Read and Write Network packets per interface and per host

a.span: ALL OS: Read/Write packets per Interface

span.title:
Network Packets in Error per interface
• Analyse the Number of Network packets that in error per interface and per host

a.span: AIX, SOLARIS: Error packets per Interface

span.title:
Network File System (NFS) Server and Client Statistics
• Analyse various NFS Client and Server Statistics, eligible for NFS version 2/3/4

Ethernet (Shared and Physical) Adapters Traffic Analysis
• Analyse Traffic Data for Shared and Physical Ethernet Adapters in Kbps / Mbps / Gbps and per host

Ethernet Shared Adapters Read/Write Packets Analysis
• Analyse Number of Read/Write packets for Shared Ethernet Adapters and per host

Nmon Baseline Analysis
• With the baseline Nmon KV Store, use this interface to analyse historical data and detect key system metrics derivations
• Key system metrics (CPU usage, Real and Virtual Memory, IOPS disk statistics) charted over the baseline
• Optionally chart current statistics over the future baseline and get realtime situation of system resources utilization

CPU Predictive Analysis Interface
• Using the predict Splunk command, this interface will help trying to estimate future load of your systems
• Choose between available algorithms: Local Level (LL), Seasonal Local Level (LLP), Local Level Trend (LLT) and LLP5 (combine LLT and LLP)

a.span: Predictive interface, forecast future using predict

span.title:
Nmon Comparison Interface
• Compare System Resources usage between 2 periods, a reference Period and arrival Period
• Choose between Main Monitors: CPU usage (CPU_ALL / LPAR), Memory, I/O, Network
• Evaluate the trend with Evolution Rate and graphical decorations to help instantly discover the comparison result

BubbleChart: TOP hosts CPU Usage
• Evaluate the TOP 100 hosts CPU load represented in Bubble Charts to instantly discover hosts responsible of the global load average
• Evaluate the TOP 20 hosts CPU load represented in d3chart bar chart
• Evaluate the full Statistics table of hosts CPU load with main hosts information

p.b: The TOP bubble chart dashboard provides a graphical view of TOP hosts using CPU, and has specific versions and/or options per operating system.

span.title:
Bullet charts Dashboard: Analysis of main system metrics in bullet charts
• TOP hosts by CPU usage / TOP hosts by physical and virtual memory usage
• TOP Commands (processes) consumming CPU and Memory in your deployment
• Advanced drilldown facilities for insight analysis

a.span: Bullet Chart: TOP Servers / TOP Processes

span.title:
Dashboard: Processes CPU and Memory Usage
• Evaluate Processes CPU and Memory usage in d3chart BubbleChart to instantly represent major Command invocations
• Represent this CPU / Memory usage in a d3chart chart over time

p.b: The TOP processes dashboard provides a graphical view of TOP hosts / processes using CPU / Memory, and has specific versions and/or options per operating system.

span.title:
D3chart: Solaris Projects / Zones / Tasks / Users CPU and Memory statistics
• Evaluate Major CPU and MEM usage items, choose between available monitors
• Represent this CPU / Memory usage in a d3chart bubblechart and statistic tables

a.span: Solaris WLM CPU and Memory Statistics

span.title:
Hosts Configuration Show Interface
• Explore the raw configuration of hosts
• The full raw host configuration is part of AAA and BBB sections of raw Nmon files

Nmon Configuration Inventory
• Explore the Nmon inventory of known hosts from your system to get valuable information
• Main configuration Items depends on Operating System: type of OS, OS version, CPU / Mem configuration and more

Data Processing Activity: Calendar
Analyse in Heatmap Calendars the Nmon Processing Activity:
• Volume of Raw Data Proceeded (in MB)
• Errors in Data Processing (Count of)
• Time Spent in Data Processing (in Seconds, conversion of NMON files)

Data Performance Activity: Calendar
Analyse in Heatmap Calendars type of Performance Data available for hosts

Application Internal Statistics
• Analyse detailed Nmon Processing Statistics: Conversion of raw Nmon data files
• Get indexes and sourcetypes Statistics
• Get Applications Statistics: Volume of Data indexes, Number of Hits per page

Data Dictionary
• Discover and Explore available data within the Nmon Splunk Application
• Filter relevant Data for AIX, Linux and Solaris systems
• Access to full metric definition: brieve and full description, relevant unity, formula...
